title: Before you begin
content:
To orchestrate and manage resources efficiently, the suite uses Kubernetes as the platform to provide a reliable approach to scheduling resources and empower the application to be more fault-tolerant. Cloud-native Kubernetes platforms make the provisioning and management of Kubernetes much easier. With the cloud-native Kubernetes, the suite can serve customers in a secure, resilient, and simple way.

On Azure, the cloud-native Kubernetes solution is Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS).

Reference architecture

The following reference architecture provides an overview of the process of deploying the suite on AKS.

Benefits of using AKS

AKS provides the following benefits:

  • There are no more control plane nodes. The cluster has a guaranteed SLA provided by Azure at a lower cost.
  • Managed worker nodes require a lower operational cost of cluster management.
  • Cloud-native services are leveraged as much as possible to ease the management experience and reduce operational cost
    • Azure Container Registry (ACR) is used as container image storage;
    • Azure NetApp Files/Azure Files and Azure Disks are used as persistent storage for the suite product.

Components

  • SMA: the suite product shipped and running in the form of containers and managed by Kubernetes.
  • Kubernetes: open-source software that allows you to deploy and manage containerized applications at scale.
  • Bastion node: a node that sits in a public subnet. It's used to connect to resources in a private subnet (such as Kubernetes, databases, and storage) to perform tasks such as deployment, persistent volume setup, database setup, upgrade, and troubleshooting.
  • Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS): a fully managed service provided by Azure. Once provisioned, the service is ready to work as a Kubernetes platform for you.
  • Azure NetApp Files (ANF): a managed NFS service that stores data such as search engine storage, attachments, certificates, and logs used by containerized applications in Kubernetes. The storage is called Persistent Volume (PV) in Kubernetes.
  • Azure Files Premium and Azure Disks: as an alternative to ANF, Azure Files Premium is a managed Server Message Block (SMB) service that stores data attachments, certificates, and logs used by containerized applications in Kubernetes; Azure Disks offers high-performance and highly durable block storage for search engine and RabbitMQ. The storage is called Persistent Volume (PV) in Kubernetes.
  • Database (self-hosted): stores transactional data and metadata used by containerized applications in Kubernetes.
  • Azure Container Registry (ACR): a managed Docker registry service that's secure, scalable, and reliable. The suite applications are shipped as container images, which are stored in an ACR.
  • Load Balancer: used to route traffic from external to internal applications deployed on Kubernetes. Load balancers triggered from the Kubernetes service are able to discover the backend worker node change and always fit into the latest status of the worker node pool.
  • Application Gateway: used to route traffic from external to internal applications deployed on Kubernetes; meanwhile, it comes with layer 7 load balancing features like SSL offloading.

Inter-communication between components

  • The Kubernetes cluster, databases, and storage are kept in a private subnet, while other components such as the load balancer and bastion node are in a public subnet. For information about why public and private subnets are separated, see the "Architecture design considerations" section below.
  • The load balancer works as the entrance of external traffic. It's usually bound with the site's SMA URL (for example https://serviceportal.microfocus.com). Once end users open the URL in their browsers or mobile apps, after DNS resolution, the load balancer routes traffic from external applications to applications in the private subnet.
  • DevOps engineers connect to the bastion node in a public subnet and then jump to the private network for cluster management. The bastion node in this scenario works as a Kubernetes client, database client, or NFS client for operation purposes.
  • The applications reside inside the Kubernetes cluster in the private subnet. It uses ANF/Azure Files as its Persistent Volume and self-built database as its database, which are also in the private subnet.

Architecture design considerations

Security

  • By separating the public and private subnets, the network infrastructure is able to provide:
    • An additional layer of security.
    • Independent routing tables configured for every private subnet to control the flow of traffic within and outside the Azure VNet.
  • All OMT and suite components are located in the private subnet. NO direct Internet access is allowed.
  • Employee Self-Service (ESS) users and IT agents can only connect to the specified ports (for example: 443) for business purposes. A typical traffic path is:
    End user/IT agent <-> Load balancer (public subnet) <-> AKS worker nodes (private subnet)
  • DevOps engineers can connect to the bastion node in a public subnet and then jump to the private network for cluster management. Only a limited number of users can access the bastion node. A typical traffic path is:
    DevOps engineer <-> Bastion node (public subnet) <-> AKS cluster or NFS or DB (private subnet)

Availability

  • The control plane nodes and worker nodes are managed by AKS with a target SLA.
  • An Azure Application Gateway and load balancer distribute the traffic across different worker nodes.
  • Azure NetApp Files/Azure Files & Azure Disks provide storage access for different worker nodes.

[Optional] Additional load balancer in front of SMAX

According to your organization's network/security requirements, you may need to setup an additional load balancer in front of Service Management.
Please enable websocket on the additional load balancer if you have installed one.

Personas

The installation process in a production environment involves different roles in your organization. For example, IT administrators manage physical or virtual machines for production use, and the person who will install the suite needs to request machines from an IT administrator, who will help prepare the requested machines. Typically the involved roles include:

Role Responsibility
Suite administrator The person with this role has to ensure the success of the entire installation including verification and post-installation tasks. This person must have a good understanding of the entire installation process, request support from other appropriate roles as needed, and complete the installation once the environment is ready for installation.
Cloud administrator The person with this role manages resources on Azure. This person grants permissions and changes roles from the Azure portal.
IT administrator The person with this role prepares physical or virtual machines as requested by the Suite Admin.
Network administrator The person with this role manages network-related configuration for your organization. This person needs to perform network configuration tasks as requested by the Suite Admin.
Storage administrator The person with this role plans and deploys all types of storage for your organization. This person needs to set up volumes required by the suite.
Database administrator The person with this role prepares and configures databases for your organization. This person needs to manage databases as requested by the Suite Admin.
Kubernetes Cluster administrator The person with this role manages Kubernetes for your organization. This person needs to create and manage the Kubernetes cluster as requested by the Suite Admin.
Server administrator The person with this role performs server-related tasks for your organization. This person needs to build and configure the bastion node.
Directory Services administrator The person with this role manages directory services for your organization. This person needs to import IDM metadata.
Security administrator The person with this role manages security-related tasks for your organization. This person needs to prepare certificates and key pairs.
